Precision positioning systems with large working stroke (millimeter or more) and micro/nano-scale positioning resolution are widely required in both scientific research and industries. For this kind of applications, piezoelectric materials based actuators show unique advantages and have been widely employed. To overcome the demerit of the limited working stroke for single piezoelectric element, various stepping motion principles have been proposed in the past years, and accordingly, stepping piezoelectric actuators with various structures have been designed and evaluated. This review is aimed to summarize the recent developments and achievements in stepping piezoelectric actuators with large working stroke. Especially, the emphasis is on three main types of stepping piezoelectric actuators, i.e., inchworm type, friction-inertia type, and parasitic type. The motion principles of these three types of piezoelectric actu-
ompliant mechanism ators and the corresponding developments of various actuators are discussed respectively, followed by pointing out the existing problems in these three types of piezoelectric actuators and proposing some potential research directions in this topic. It is expected that this review is helpful for relevant researchers to understand stepping motion principles as well as piezoelectric actuators, and to successfully select and design stepping piezoelectric actuators for specific applications.

2. Inchworm type piezoelectric actuators
2.1. Introduction to the inchworm motion principle
The inchworm type piezoelectric actuator is one kind of novel actuators, and it mimics the motion principle of the real inchworm in nature, as shown in Fig. 1(a) [32]. By combining the stepping motion of the natural inchworm with piezoelectric technology, the inchworm type piezoelectric actuator achieves the large working stroke through the alternating cooperation of the driving units and clamping units. Meanwhile, the utilization of clamping units brings large output force, compared with other piezoelectric actuators. Generally, an early inchworm type piezoelectric actuator consists of one driving unit and two clamping units. According to the motion principle, inchworm type piezoelectric actuators are divided into three patterns: “walker” pattern, “pusher” pattern and hybrid “walker-pusher” pattern [20].
The motion principle of the “walker” pattern inchworm piezoelectric actuator is illustrated in Fig. 1(b), which is quite similar to the walking pattern of the inchworm in nature. The “walker” mechanism obtains large working stroke by repeating the following six steps: (1) in the original position, all of the piezoelectric elements inside the driving unit and clamping units are not working; hence there are gaps between the clamping units and the base guider; (2) the piezoelectric actuator in clamping unit 1 gets power, and then the clamping unit 1 holds the base guider tightly; (3) the driving unit gets power to extend; (4) the clamping unit 2 obtains power to hold the base guider tightly, together with the clamping unit 1; (5) the clamping unit 1 loses power to release the base guider; (6) the driving unit retracts to its original length. Finally, the clamping unit 2 loses power to release the base guider, which is in the same condition with the original position in step (1). By repeating these six steps, large working stroke could be achieved step by step [33,34].
The “pusher” pattern inchworm piezoelectric actuator also requires six steps to obtain one stepping motion, as shown in Fig. 1(c): (1) the driving unit and two clamping units have no power to hold the slider; (2) clamping unit 2 gets power to hold the slider tightly; (3) the driving unit extends to push clamping unit 2 and the slider to move a small distance; (4) clamping unit 1 clamps the slider tightly; (5) clamping unit 2 loses power to release the slider; (6) the driving unit retracts to the original length. Finally, the clamping unit 1 releases the slider to the same situation in the original condition [35,36].
The hybrid “walker-pusher” pattern inchworm piezoelectric actuator is the mixture of the “walker” and “pusher” patterns. Differently, the driving unit is inserted into the slider, and the clamping units are assembled into the base in this “walker-pusher” pattern [37,38].

. Friction-inertia type piezoelectric actuators
.1. Introduction to the friction-inertia motion principle
The motion principle of friction-inertia type piezoelectric actutors is based on the law of momentum conservation. By applying pecial voltage signal, for example the saw-tooth wave, to piezolectric stacks or piezoelectric bimorphs, the relative displacement etween two mass blocks with different weight is produced, and hus the stepping motion is realized. The most significant merit f friction-inertia type piezoelectric actuators is that their strucures are quite simple, and so as the control system. Therefore, he friction-inertia piezoelectric actuator is gaining more and more

According to the motion principle, friction-inertia piezoelectric actuators can be classified into two groups [68,69]: the impact-drive piezoelectric actuator (so called impact-drive mechanism, IDM) [70–72] and the stick-slip piezoelectric actuator (so called smooth impact-drive mechanism, SIDM) [73–75].
The motion principle of the impact-drive piezoelectric actuator is shown in Fig. 6(a). This kind of actuator is mainly composed of two mass blocks (main block and inertial block) and one piezoelectric element [76]. The whole structure is placed on the surface of the friction base. At the beginning, the piezoelectric element is not charged, which means the length of the piezoelectric element is the shortest. Then, in step (2), the driving voltage of the piezoelectric element gradually increases, and the piezoelectric element extends slowly. Since the mass of the main block is larger than that of the inertial block, the main block keeps no motion due to the friction force from the ground, while the inertial block moves to the right slightly. Afterwards, in step (3), the piezoelectric element loses power suddenly and it retracts to the minimum length rapidly as that in step (1). In this case, the inertial force is greater than the friction force from the ground, and the two blocks move to the opposite sides, respectively. As a result, the impact-drive piezoelectric actuator moves to the right with one-step length S, as shown in Fig. 6(a). By repeating the above steps, a large working stroke is easily obtained.
Fig. 6(b) illustrates the working process of the stick-slip piezoelectric actuator which is also called the smooth impact-drive actuator [68,77]. Being different from the impact-drive piezoelectric actuator, one end of the piezoelectric element in stick-slip piezoelectric actuator is fixed on the base, while the other end is connected with the friction block. The slider is placed on the surface of the friction block. In the motion process, step (2), the piezoelectric element slowly extends, and the slider moves to the right side due to the role of friction force between the slider and friction block. This process is also called the s̈ticks̈tage since there is no relative motion between the friction block and the slider. Then, in step (3), the piezoelectric element quickly loses power and returns back to the original length, but the slider is kept almost no motion due to the role of the inertial force. This process is called the s̈lips̈tage because of the relative motion between the friction block and the slider. By repeating the “stick” and “slip” stages, the slider can realize continuously stepping motion and the working stroke is infinite in theory.
For the stick-slip piezoelectric actuators, in the case that the driving frequency is high enough, stick-slip motion principle shifts to slip-slip principle, which means that there is always relative motion between the slider and the friction block (no s̈ticks̈tage). 4. Parasitic type piezoelectric actuators
4.1. Introduction to the parasitic motion
The parasitic motion, the motion generated together with the major motion, is commonly reduced and even avoided during the design of piezoelectric actuators, because it leads to additional positioning errors for positioning systems. As shown in Fig. 11(a), when a force F is applied on the tip of a cantilever beam, the beam will bend and two motions will appear. The motion displacement x is the major motion caused by the force F, while the displacement y is called the parasitic motion generated due to the bending of the cantilever beam. In other words, one input force F generates two motions in different directions. In general, the parasitic motion y is smaller compared with the major motion x, and it will bring additional motion of the positioning system, resulting in positioning error or unstable motion. Nevertheless, if the parasitic motion of compliant mechanism is adopted into the design of piezoelectric actuators, a novel parasitic type piezoelectric actuator with large working stroke and high resolution is easily achieved.
4.2. Developments and performances
As shown in Fig. 11(b), Huang et al. firstly proposed the parasitic type piezoelectric actuator in 2012 based on the parasitic motion of a micro-gripper [116]. In the ordinary way, the microgripper is utilized to hold microscale objects, which means that the clamping displacement x is the major motion displacement. Nevertheless, as shown in Fig. 11(b), in the case that the microgripper is working, the output end not only moves in x direction, but also in y direction. Here, the motion displacement y in y direction is the so called parasitic motion of the micro-gripper. The two ends of the mover are placed in the middle of the clamping gap of the micro-gripper, as illustrated in the three-dimensional (3D) model of the actuator in Fig. 11(b). Hence, the parasitic motion y will pull the mover to move a small distance along y direction. With the help of saw-tooth voltage wave, the piezoelectric stack extends slowly but retracts quickly, which leads to the stepping motion of the mover. Jianping Li was born in Jiangsu, China, in 1987. He received the B.S. degree and Ph. D degree from the School of Mechanical Science and Engineering, Jilin University, Changchun, China, in 2011 and 2016, respectively. His current research interests include piezoelectric actuators and the application of electrical impedance spectroscopy in biomedical science.
Hu Huang was born in Hubei, China, in 1986. He received his B.E. and Ph.D. degrees in mechanical engineering from Jilin University, Changchun, China, in 2010 and 2014, respectively. Supported by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS), he worked as a Research Fellow at Keio University from 2014 to 2017. Currently, He is a full professor at Jilin University. His research interests include precision machines and instruments, mechanical properties of materials, and surface modification of materials.
Takeshi Morita received B. Eng., M. Eng. and Dr. Eng. degrees in precision machinery engineering from the University of Tokyo in 1994, 1996, and 1999, respectively. metadata.abstractText: Precision positioning systems with large working stroke (millimeter or more) and micro/nano-scale positioning resolution are widely required in both scientific research and industries. For this kind of applications, piezoelectric materials based actuators show unique advantages and have been widely employed. To overcome the demerit of the limited working stroke for single piezoelectric element, various stepping motion principles have been proposed in the past years, and accordingly, stepping piezoelectric actuators with various structures have been designed and evaluated. This review is aimed to summarize the recent developments and achievements in stepping piezoelectric actuators with large working stroke. Especially, the emphasis is on three main types of stepping piezoelectric actuators, i.e., inchworm type, friction-inertia type, and parasitic type. The motion principles of these three types of piezoelectric actuompliant mechanism ators and the corresponding developments of various actuators are discussed respectively, followed by pointing out the existing problems in these three types of piezoelectric actuators and proposing some potential research directions in this topic. It is expected that this review is helpful for relevant researchers to understand stepping motion principles as well as piezoelectric actuators, and to successfully select and design stepping piezoelectric actuators for specific applications. © 2019 Elsevier B.V.
